text: Thou shalt arise, and have mercy upon Zion: for the time to favour her, yea, the set time, is come.
text_kjv: Thou shalt arise, and have mercy upon Zion: for the time to favour her, yea, the set time, is come.
text_niv: You will arise and have compassion on Zion,for it is time to show favor to her;the appointed time has come.
text_esv: You will arise and have pity on Zion; it is the time to favor her; the appointed time has come.
text_nlt: You will arise and have mercy on Jerusalem —and now is the time to pity her,now is the time you promised to help.
text_msg: You'll get up from your throne and help Zion—it's time for compassionate help.
text_nasb: You will arise [and] have compassion on Zion; For it is time to be gracious to her, For the appointed time has come.
context: Psalm 102 is a lament, a prayer from someone deeply afflicted and likely in exile. Understanding the historical backdrop requires recognizing the trauma of the Babylonian exile, which began in 586 BC with the destruction of Jerusalem and the Temple. This event scattered the Jewish people, stripping them of their land, their religious center, and their national identity. The Psalmist likely identifies with the collective suffering of the exiled community. Zion, synonymous with Jerusalem and the Temple, was not merely a place; it represented God's presence, covenant, and the hope of restoration. The psalm echoes the longing for a return to normalcy, for God's favor to be restored. The "set time" referred to in verse 13 might connect to prophecies concerning the duration of the exile, found in Jeremiah and Daniel. These prophecies provided a framework for hope, suggesting God had predetermined a moment of release. The Psalm's language also draws upon established covenantal theology, reminding God of his promises to David and his descendants. The author pleads not solely for personal relief, but for the restoration of Zion, recognizing that individual well-being is inextricably linked to the fate of the community. Knowing the desperation of exile and the importance of Zion as the center of Jewish faith and hope is crucial to grasping the weight of this verse. It speaks to a desperate yearning for divine intervention in a time of profound crisis.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 102:13 is a powerful assertion of God's sovereignty and covenant faithfulness. The phrase "Thou shalt arise" points to God's active involvement in human history. It's not a passive hope, but a direct appeal for divine action. God isn't merely an observer; He is invited to intervene on behalf of His people. The concept of "mercy upon Zion" emphasizes God's character as compassionate and forgiving. It acknowledges the people's sin, which led to the exile, yet pleads for grace and restoration. The statement that "the time to favour her, yea, the set time, is come" is crucial. It suggests that God operates according to a divine plan and timetable. There is a divinely appointed moment for deliverance, implying that even in suffering, God is in control and has a purpose. This "set time" reinforces the idea of God's covenant with Israel. The exile was a consequence of breaking the covenant, but God's promise to restore them remained. This verse highlights the tension between God's judgment and His mercy, demonstrating that even in the midst of punishment, God remembers His promises. It also speaks to the enduring nature of God's love for His chosen people. The Psalm's plea for Zion reflects a deep understanding of the importance of the Temple as a place of worship and atonement. The destruction of the Temple was a symbolic and literal representation of the broken relationship between God and His people, and its restoration was essential for reconciliation.
application: Psalm 102:13 offers profound application for modern believers navigating personal and societal challenges. Firstly, it encourages us to actively seek God's intervention in difficult situations. We should not passively accept suffering but boldly petition God to "arise" and act on our behalf. This verse reminds us that God is not distant but actively involved in the affairs of humanity. Secondly, it teaches us about the importance of timing in God's plan. While we may not always understand why God doesn't answer our prayers immediately, this verse assures us that He has a "set time" for everything. This requires patience and trust, knowing that God's timing is perfect, even when it differs from our own desires. Thirdly, it challenges us to show compassion and advocate for justice on behalf of others. Just as the Psalmist prayed for the restoration of Zion, we should be mindful of the suffering of those around us and work towards their healing and liberation. This could involve supporting marginalized communities, advocating for social change, or simply offering a listening ear to someone in need. Furthermore, it prompts us to evaluate our own lives and seek God's mercy. We should acknowledge our shortcomings and ask for forgiveness, trusting in God's grace to restore us to right relationship with Him. The concept of a "set time" also invites reflection on our own life purpose. God has a plan for each of us, and this verse challenges us to discern that plan and live in accordance with it. We should seek to align our actions with God's will, trusting that He will guide us and empower us to fulfill our purpose. Finally, it emphasizes the enduring hope we have in God. Even in the darkest of times, we can cling to the promise that God will eventually act on our behalf and bring about restoration and healing.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before you acknowledging your sovereignty and power. We ask you to arise and have mercy upon us, your people. We see the brokenness and pain in our world, in our communities, and in our own lives. Lord, we trust that you have a "set time" for all things. Give us patience to wait on your timing and faith to believe in your promises. Fill us with compassion for those who are suffering and empower us to be instruments of your healing and justice. Forgive us for our shortcomings and restore us to right relationship with you. Help us to discern your will for our lives and to live in accordance with your purpose. We thank you for your enduring love and faithfulness. In Jesus' name, we pray. Amen.

faqs.answer: The phrase "arise" is anthropomorphic language, attributing human-like actions to God. It symbolizes God actively intervening in human affairs, moving from a state of seeming inaction to a state of powerful intervention, often to deliver or judge.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse: What does it mean for God to 'arise'?

faqs.answer: Zion represented more than just a place; it symbolized the center of Jewish religious and national life. It was the location of the Temple, God's dwelling place, and the heart of their covenant relationship. Restoration of Zion meant restoration of their faith and nation.
faqs.question: Q2: Why is Zion specifically mentioned and not just all the Israelites?

faqs.answer: The "set time" suggests God's foreknowledge and planning, but doesn't necessarily negate free will. It speaks to God's control over history, while individuals still make choices that have consequences, yet still fit into God's ultimate plan.
faqs.question: Q3: Does 'the set time' imply predestination, and does that limit free will?

faqs.answer: This verse serves as a reminder to trust in God's timing, even when it doesn't align with our own desires. It reinforces the belief that God has a plan and a purpose, even in suffering, and that He will eventually act according to His perfect will.
faqs.question: Q4: How can this verse be helpful when it seems God isn't answering prayers or intervening in situations?

faqs.answer: Absolutely. The principle of God's timing and intervention can be applied to individual struggles, illnesses, or difficult circumstances. It encourages believers to seek God's mercy and trust that He will act in His own time and way to bring healing and restoration.
faqs.question: Q5: Can this verse apply to personal situations beyond national restoration?
